text: DEREK THOMAS, M.D., the witness, having been first duly sworn, was deposed and testified as follows: EXAMINATION ON QUALIFICATIONS
Good afternoon, Doctor.
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Hello.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would you please you introduce yourself to the jury?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: I'm Dr. Derek Thomas.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And we are here today to take your testimony on behalf of one of your patients and one of my clients, Carlos Hawthorne following his January 2017 motor vehicle accident.  Any opinions you formed as an expert in this case as a result of that treatment and evaluation -- before we get there, I would like to ask you a couple questions about your qualifications so the jury understands why you're here and what your qualifications are. Can you tell me what type of physician you are.
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Orthopedic surgeon.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what does that mean?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Orthopedics is a study of bone and joint disorders.  In my case, specifically, I only deal with adult spinal problems.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And can you estimate for me what percentage of the patients you see require surgery?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Probably -- I see about 120 patients per week and I do about eight spine surgeries a week.  But in that 120 patients are mostly non-operative patients, some are patients we've already operated on.  So I'm not sure how those numbers work out but that's what I see.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Fair enough. Are you licensed to practice in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you told us already you focus on adult spine surgery.  Can you tell the jury how you became a surgeon.
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Sure.  Went to four years of college, University of Notre Dame.  Medical school at the Medical College of Virginia followed by a five-year orthopedic surgery residency in South Carolina, followed by a one-year adult spine surgery fellowship at Stanford.  And then returned to Pittsburgh and started working.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you board certified?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In what specialty?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Orthopedics.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is board certification?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Board certification in orthopedics means at the end of your five years of residency you have to take a written test.  If you pass the written test then two years later you take an oral examination.  And if you pass that then you're considered board certified.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you been published in the field?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And have you previously been qualified to testify as an expert witness in Allegheny County?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you do work for both plaintiff and defense firms?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm going to show you -- well, please take a look at the document I've marked as Exhibit 1 in front of you; do you recognize that?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes, that's my CV.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: (Dr. Thomas Deposition Exhibit No. 1 was marked for identification.)
And can you tell me a little bit about your current practice.
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Current practice is, as I said, 120 patients a week.  About eight surgeries a week. Mostly -- 99 percent of what I do revolves around adult spine surgery.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you have operating privileges at any hospitals around here?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: St. Clair Hospital.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that where you primarily practice now?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what kind of procedures do you perform on a weekly basis?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Most common surgeries I do are lumbar fusions, cervical or neck fusions and lumbar and microdiscectomies.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And as part of your practice, do you diagnose and treat patients who have been injured in auto accidents and other accidents?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you treat people with neck and back injuries?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: As part of your practice do you routinely review and rely on medical records and diagnostic records from other providers?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And does your training include the ability to read and evaluate diagnostic records?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes, it does.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would that include MRIs?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you, Doctor, I don't have any other questions on your qualifications ,Mr. Olszewski may.
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Thank you, Doctor, just one or two questions. CROSS-EXAMINATION ON QUALIFICATIONS
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: I see on your curriculum vitae that you identified earlier that it lists your employer as Greater Pittsburgh Orthopaedic Associates.  Are you still with that organization?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: No, I moved to St. Clair Orthopedics three months ago.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So other than that change to your curriculum vitae, are all the other bits of information here accurate and correct?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the move from Greater Pittsburgh Orthopaedic Associates to St. Clair Hospital, has that in any way changed the practice that you do and the operations that you perform?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: No further questions.  Thank you. DIRECT EXAMINATION ON QUALIFICATIONS CON'T
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Doctor, at the time of Mr. Hawthorne's surgery, November of 2017, were you working at Greater Pittsburgh Orthopaedics?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you.  I would offer Dr. Derek Thomas as an expert in the field of orthopedics and orthopedic surgery.
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: No objection. DIRECT EXAMINATION
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: As I mentioned before, we're here to talk about Carlos Hawthorne and what happened to him after he was rear ended back in January of 2017.  During your testimony I'm going to ask you for a couple of opinions today.  So I'm going to put a qualifier on that; please don't give me any opinions unless you can do so to a reasonable degree of medical certainty; is that fair?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, my office asked you to prepare a narrative report in this case.  Would you take a look at Exhibit 2 please.
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: (Dr. Thomas Deposition Exhibit No. 2 was marked for identification.)
Is that the report you prepared on Mr. Hawthorne's behalf?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes, it is.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When did you first see Carlos.
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: I first met Mr. Hawthorne on September 22, 2017.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you evaluate him, yourself, in person?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you, in fact, his surgeon?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you perform a physical exam when you first encountered him?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.  When I saw him on that day he was, I believe, 42 years old.  Reported a motor vehicle accident of January 23, 2017.  He had told me he had been through some other nonoperative treatments.  And so when I saw him we -- on physical exam that day, basically what he had was a pretty classic L5-S1 problem towards the left side.  He had weakness in his plantar flexion, in other words couldn't stand on his toes (indicating) on that left side. He had no ankle jerk reflex on the left side compared to the right.  Once again, consistent with a S1 nerve problem.  Positive straight leg raise test.  Just a basic test we do to investigate these types of problems.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how is the straight leg test performed?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: He had a positive straight leg raise test.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How do you perform that test?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Should have him lying down, then you raise the leg up, you get to a certain level and they start recomplaining of pain which goes down their leg.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when he presented to your office, did you have the benefit of an MRI at that time?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you tell the jury what an MRI is.
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: MRI is magnetic resonance imaging. It's a wonderful type of image we have that shows us great anatomical pictures of the spine.  And in this case, the ones I look at the most are lumbar and cervical MRIs which show the discs, the nerves, the bones and potential pinching of nerves.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Let's start with the conclusion in this case.  Was he injured in this accident?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: I believe he had a herniated disc at L5-S1 towards the left side.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And is this a surgical case?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Well, at first we try to treat most people nonoperatively, as he went through several months of trying to treat this nonoperatively, but if the pain persists and weakness, even some numbness, loss of reflex, those are all good surgical indications.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you perform surgery on Carlos?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What kind of procedure?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: L5-S1 microdiscectomy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And can you tell the jury what that is.
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Sure.  So, I'll just go to the model here.  I will show you the model.  This is a model of the spine.  What you have here are bones and in between are discs.  You can see the yellow nerves coming out the side and -- a disc is like a jelly doughnut, if you squeeze it hard enough a piece of jelly can come out through the back and hit on one of these nerves. In his case, his disc comes outs of the left side in the back, hits on the S1 nerve like this and sends the pain down the back of his left leg down to his foot.  When that piece of jelly comes out it impinges upon the nerve.  And when you do a surgery for this, what we basically do is the patient is asleep, we flip the patient over, we make a small incision in the back and then we'll drill a hole in the bone on this side; that's called a laminotomy.  Underneath that is going to be some ligament.  You slowly remove away the ligament until you see the nerve.  Take the nerve and pull it to the side and, underneath that, you should see the piece of herniated disc sitting there (indicating throughout).
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In this case, did you see pieces of herniated disc sitting there?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you remove that disc?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Sure.  You basically -- what happens is the piece of jelly that comes out basically forms a little capsule around it and you just pop it (indicating) and out -- comes out a couple fragments, maybe one nice big fragment if you're really lucky, but usually it comes out in two or three fragments of disc.  And you remove that and the nerve is able to fall back down to where it's supposed to be, it gives it more room and people wake up and feel better.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is the interplay between Mr. Hawthorne's symptoms of having difficulty walking, difficulty sitting and the lack of a reflex correlated with that lumbar herniation?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: So an L5-S1 herniation usually, as I said, describes pain in the back, pain in the buttock area, pain down the leg; it can be numbness and tingling; it can be a loss of reflex like he has.  In other words, the nerve is pinched and you do not get your normal reflexes like you're supposed to have.  People with herniated discs often will have the leg symptoms, they can often have back pain.  A lot of these people have trouble sitting.  The way I describe them as, they're very fidgety people, in other words they can't sit very long, can't stand very long, really can't walk very long either.  They're kind of always of moving around because nothing is very comfortable for them.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I would like to look the at actual MRI in this case.  Did you use the films yourself?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Off the record please. VIDEOGRAPHER
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: (Brief recess from 5:28 p.m. - 5:29 p.m.) VIDEOGRAPHER:  Back on record.  Time is 5:29.
Doctor, what are we looking at here?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: This is called -- this is a cross-section of the lumbar spine at L5-S1.  In other words, cross-section means if we cut you off and look down at you or really look up at you, but -- and what you see here is, there's our disc, kind of like a jelly doughnut, dark on the outside, kind of jelly in the middle. These are your nerves back here, the little black things bathing in white spinal fluid. This is the left side.  That's the right.  And if we come down one frame you can see a piece of disc that's come out this side over here impinging upon the nerves on this side, versus the nerve on the right side has plenty of room.  So that's a pretty classic herniated disc towards the left side (indicating throughout).
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And are those nerves the nerves you showed us on the model that go down the legs?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Correct.  The S1 nerve begins right about there (indicating).
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And with that nerve, where should -- where would a classic presentation of pathology present?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Pretty much how I described it, back pain, buttock pain, back of the leg pain, kind of your hamstring area down to your calf.  And if it gets really specific, as I said, you can start losing some strength or even a reflex on that side.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you.
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Off the record. VIDEOGRAPHER
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: (Brief recess from 5:30 p.m. - 5:31 p.m.) VIDEOGRAPHER:  Back on record.  Time is 5:31.
Doctor, you mentioned when he first presented to you in September he had already gone through some nonoperative care.  Could you tell the jury what kind of treatment he had?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: He had told me he had been through some chiropractic treatments for several months.  Had had at least one, I think, maybe two epidural injections or steroid injections in the back.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What are the goal of those treatments?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Well, about 60 percent of herniated discs will just get better if you treat them nonoperatively.  That still leaves about 30 or 40 percent that don't get better.  Chiropractic treatments, epidural injections are all there to try to help with the pain and the symptoms in hopes that the body will just continue to get better over time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And is that -- is the standard of care prior to these operations to try some nonoperative --
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- interventions?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  What -- what's significant about the loss of reflex in the leg?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: It's just a sign that you see on physical exam that the nerve is pinched.  If it's pinched for a while, it doesn't even have to be that long, but people can lose the reflex, it's just something we look for on physical exam.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when you first saw him did you schedule the surgery right after that initial operation -- or after the initial visit?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: I believe we did, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Because his surgery was then done on November 6th.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And where is -- where do you perform these surgeries?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: This surgery was done, I believe, at St. Clair Hospital.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is the patient put under?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes, they are asleep.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you remove that fragment, is that you in there with a knife physically?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So this isn't a laser procedure or anything like this, you physically open them up?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are there stitches involved?  Is there a scar involved?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yeah, a scar for a guy like him is probably about an inch, maybe an inch and a quarter.  The stitches are all put under the skin.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And immediately postoperatively what does this mean for Mr. Hawthorne's life?  What's his recovery like?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Most people that you do the surgery on, if you've chosen the patient well and they have an MRI like that, they should feel an instant change. They should know it from the moment they wake up, they should feel some difference, at least a decrease in their leg pain.  The back usually is pretty sore just from where we cut them for at least, you know, two, three weeks. As far as recovery, most people who have a labor job we likely will not let them to get back to heavy labor for about eight weeks, two months, somewhere in there.  If they have some sort of desk job or light-duty job they can probably get back sooner than that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you take Carlos off of work?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I saw a note in your file that he can return the 22nd of November.  Does that sound right to you?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Is that typical for someone who has a desk-type job?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes, I think that's pretty good.  Yeah, that's maybe a little earlier than some of our patients but, yeah, two weeks is great.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And do you have an opinion as to the cause of the injuries you told us about earlier?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: I do believe it does date back to the motor vehicle accident, January of 2017.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you hold that opinion to a reasonable degree of medical certainty?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Has the treatment that Carols Hawthorne's had to date, including the surgery, been reasonable and necessary?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And have you given us all of your opinions today to a reasonable degree of medical certainty?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you Doctor, I don't have anything further for you.
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: I do have a few questions. CROSS-EXAMINATION
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Doctor, let me ask you a little bit about your evaluation of Mr. Hawthorne.  I know that you've indicated to us here in the room and the jury that you believe that Mr. Hawthorne's need for the surgery was related to the January 23, 2017, accident.  Have I accurately summarized what you've told us today?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, what information did you have on the accident, was it only from Mr. Hawthorne or for from some other source?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes, Mr. Hawthorne.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And based on the description of what Mr. Hawthorne told you, that is the basis for you to say that the surgery that he had to undergo was related to that event?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that typical that you would base your medical opinion on what the patient tells you?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you not need to review records or anything of that nature to give you, I guess, more of a basis for your opinion on that point?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Sometimes it's nice to but not always. I mean, we try to listen to our patients a best we can and try to believe them as best we can.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you ask Mr. Hawthorne if he did anything else between January 23 and 2017, and when you saw him on September 22 that would have impacted his back in any way?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: He did not report anything.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you ask him?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: I'm sure we discussed things, I don't have it written down in any notes.  But he did go through the chiropractic and epidural injections which is pretty typical for most people.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But do you have a recollection of asking him if he did anything to his back after January 23, 2017, until you first saw him on September 22?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay. So then Mr. Hawthorne comes to you after receiving some therapy, and you've described that in general today.  Just so I understand, Mr. Hawthorne was working when he came to see you on September 22, 2017, was he not?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: He works in an office setting; is that correct?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was able to return to work, do you recall that being sometime in March of 2017?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: We had -- I believe I released him back to full duty in November of 2017.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: No, I understand.  But what I was asking -- and maybe you don't have that in your notes there and I understand that. But were you aware then that Mr. Hawthorne was released to do his time-of-injury job -- I think there was some accommodations made -- but he was released to his time-of-injury job as of March 2017.
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: I know that he was working when I did see him, so that makes sense, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  All right. And I suppose that someone with the condition that you've described, the herniation, they can work; is that right?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: A lot of times, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I think that you've told us in a lot of cases, 60 percent, I think was your number, those people with herniations do not require surgery, they can recover without the need for surgery?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes, definitely.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was Mr. Hawthorne's problem, the area that you've shown us on the video screen, was that a problem that could resolve without surgery?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Some do, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In this case you thought surgery was the appropriate way to go?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you performed the surgery as you've done on many, many other patients, I understand?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you do the surgery that you performed on Mr. Hawthorne on a monthly, weekly basis?  I mean, how often do you do that type of surgery?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Every week.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I know no surgeries are routine, but is it a surgery that you're very familiar with?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you were doing the surgery, when you were performing the operation as you've described for us today, did you see anything else in there that would have caused you to be concerned about Mr. Hawthorne's ability to recover, I won't say fully, but to a large degree from the procedure?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I think that you've told us today and you've written it in some documentation, that Mr. Hawthorne did make a very good recovery from the surgery?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So when you last saw him in November of 2017, you released him to return to his time-of-injury job?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes, I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I understand that that release was without restrictions; is that correct?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I also understand that you saw Mr. Hawthorne back in your office on July 10, 2018, the following year; is that correct?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And why did you see him back the following year?  Did you think there would be a problem or was this just a follow-up, your routine, why did you see him again?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: He came back to see us.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when you saw Mr. Hawthorne on July 10, 2018, was he, again, in good shape and there were no problems noted?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: That's what he reported, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: As of July 10, 2018, did you see anything in Mr. Hawthorne's exam or any descriptions that he provided you which would indicate that he could not continue working in his time-of-injury capacity?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you make any follow-up or schedule any follow-up appointments for Mr. Hawthorne after July 10?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was he only to come back to you if he had a problem?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And as of today, when you're providing us with your testimony, has Mr. Hawthorne been back to see you?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would that indicate to you that he is recovered from the problems that you treated him for?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Hopefully, he's doing well, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you happy with the surgery that you performed?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yeah, his was great.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Is this the result that you like to see in a lot of your patients?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yeah, I would love to.  Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So this was a very positive result --
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- that Mr. Hawthorne received --
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yeah, surgery was simple, recovery was easy.  Pain went away quickly.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Does it help in Mr. Hawthorne's case that he's a fairly young man --
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Well --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- 42 years old.  Does that impact in the positive?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: No.  No.  I think the younger people do worse.  The older the patient the better.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Oh, okay.  But whatever the case, in Mr. Hawthorne's situation, the result was great, he's back to work and you're not seeing him any further; is that correct?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Doctor, if Mr. Hawthorne had complaints about, you know, ongoing problems, in your mind that would not be related to your surgery would it?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: No, I wouldn't think so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you put any limitations, Doctor, on Mr. Hawthorne's ability to drive or walk?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: For the first couple weeks we ask that they not drive.  We encourage them to walk every day.  But after we put them back to work, no, no restrictions.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And would that be the same for -- I know he's got a very large dog, 130 pounds or something -- any restrictions on ability to take care of his dog?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And obviously no restrictions on his ability to work?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Doctor, would you have released Mr. Hawthorne to work and the activities that you mentioned if you were uncomfortable with his recovery in any way?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: I may have held him a little bit longer, sure.  I mean, I'm very happy when patients comes in after two weeks and say they want to go back to work; that's great.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: I have a lot of people, even with desk jobs who still even take three, four, five, six weeks; just depends on what their desk job is. You know, some people are really stuck in a desk and that probably doesn't feel too great for eight or ten hours a day but...  No, but if they come in and, at two weeks, if this -- a gentleman like this says they can go back, sure, that's great.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You were happy with that result?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you're happy to accommodate him?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Doctor, you mentioned that you thought -- last, last topic area -- you thought that all of the care that Mr. Hawthorne had received up to the point when you saw him in September was reasonable and necessary, I think you said something to that effect?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How close did you look at that procedure to come up with that opinion?  Did you have all the records in front of you?  Did you scour that to determine what was necessary and not necessary?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: The general progression of things after a herniated disc, most patients you will see usually go through some form of physical therapy, some form of -- and/or chiropractic treatment.  A lot will have at least one, if not two injections. So that's pretty standard. So when I did review the records that were given to me to look at these things, I mean, it all seemed pretty reasonable as far as how you would treat people nonoperatively who just come into the office.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Doctor, was there any chance in this case that Mr. Hawthorne could have gotten to the point where he is now without the surgery that you performed?
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: I think it's probably unlikely.  You know, he's a classic example of someone who has, you know, quote/unquote failed nonoperative treatment.  You know, they come to see you three, four, five, six months after the pain begins. They've been through nonoperative things.  They start progressing -- unfortunately he was starting to get some weakness in his leg and those are the good people to operate on.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I think those are all of my questions, Doctor.  Thank you very much for your time today.
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Thank you.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Just one follow up for you. REDIRECT EXAMINATION
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Why do you ask them not to drive after the surgery?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: For the first two weeks we ask people not to drive usually because we write them for some narcotic medication afterwards and it's just easier to tell people no driving for two weeks.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Fair enough.  That's all I have.
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Nothing further.  Thank you Doctor.
speaker: MR. OLSZEWSKI

text: Thank you. VIDEOGRAPHER
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: (Witness excused.)
(Signature waived.)
(Videotaped Deposition concluded at 5:44 p.m.)
